required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Long Term Safety of Vedolizumab (MLN0002) in Patients With Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Phase 2, Multiple Dose, Open-Label Study to Determine the Long Term Safety of MLN0002 in Patients With Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease

brief_summary.textblock: This was an open-label study to provide an opportunity for participants with Ulcerative Colitis (UC) who previously completed Study C13002 (NCT01177228), and for treatment-naïve participants with UC or Crohn's Disease (CD) to receive treatment with vedolizumab, and to determine the long term safety of vedolizumab in patients afflicted with these diseases.

detailed_description.textblock:
This was a phase 2, multiple-dose, open-label study of vedolizumab administered intravenously (IV) every 8 weeks. The study population included treatment-naïve ulcerative colitis (UC) or Crohn's Disease (CD) participants, as well as 38 UC participants who had tolerated vedolizumab well during Study C13002 (NCT01177228).
In the original study protocol, all participants were randomized to receive vedolizumab at doses of either 6 mg/kg or 10 mg/kg. With the implementation of Amendment 1, the assigned doses of vedolizumab were decreased to 2.0 mg/kg and 6.0 mg/kg. To implement the dose changes, instead of randomizing all participants across both doses, those who rolled over from Study C13002 were reassigned to receive the 2.0 mg/kg dose and all participants who entered C13004 naïve to treatment were to receive the 6.0 mg/kg dose, starting on the next scheduled dosing day. Also, if participants assigned to the 2 mg/kg dose experienced flare, they were to receive the higher 6 mg/kg dose.
In the results analyses for this study, participants are grouped according to the lowest dose received, i.e., 2.0 mg/kg or 6.0 mg/kg vedolizumab.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs)
primary_outcome.description: An adverse event (AE) is any untoward medical occurrence in a patient administered a pharmaceutical product, which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the treatment. The investigator systematically collected information adequate to determine both the outcome and severity of the AE, and whether or not it was drug-related or met the criteria for classification as a serious adverse event (SAE). An SAE was defined as an AE that resulted in (or posed risk for) death, inpatient hospitalization (or prolonging hospitalization), or congenital, persistent or significant disability/incapacity. The intensity for each AE was defined according to the following criteria: Mild: Awareness of sign or symptom, but easily tolerated; Moderate: Discomfort enough to cause interference with normal daily activities; Severe: Inability to perform normal daily activities.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Significant Laboratory Findings
primary_outcome.description: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) are enzymes in the blood.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Signs and Symptoms of Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)
primary_outcome.description: At every visit, before receiving study treatment participants were evaluated by clinic staff for signs of PML using a PML symptom checklist.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Human Anti-human Antibodies (HAHA)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Samples collected prior to dosing on Days 1, 43, 155, 267, 379, 491, and 637.

secondary_outcome.measure: Serum Concentration of Vedolizumab Before Dosing
secondary_outcome.description: Vedolizumab serum concentrations were measured from serum samples collected for pharmacokinetic (PK) analysis within 2 hours prior to dosing. The original protocol specified that PK parameters, including but not limited to minimum plasma concentration (Cmin), were to be estimated; however, due to intrapatient dose modification with Amendment 1, it was no longer feasible to perform a full PK parameter estimation. The summaries of pre-infusion data (i.e., trough levels) are presented at time points where at least 50% of participants had quantifiable vedolizumab concentrations, using a value of 0 for results below a measurable range. This provides information on the pharmacokinetic behavior of vedolizumab when administered as long-term therapy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Saturation of Receptors by Vedolizumab Before Dosing on Days 1, 43, 99, 155 and 267 by ACT-1 Assay
secondary_outcome.description: The target of vedolizumab is α4β7 integrin, a receptor found on inflammatory immune cells that guides these inflammatory cells to the gut and binds to the Mucosal Addressin Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on gut endothelial cells. The extent of the α4β7 receptor saturation by vedolizumab was assessed using the ACT-1 binding interference assay. ACT-1 is a mouse antibody similar to vedolizumab that also binds α4β7 integrin. The assay measures the percentage of cells bearing α4β7 that were not saturated with vedolizumab at the time of sampling.

secondary_outcome.measure: Saturation of Receptors by Vedolizumab Before Dosing Using the MAdCAM-1-Fc Assay
secondary_outcome.description: The target of vedolizumab is α4β7 integrin, a receptor found on inflammatory immune cells that guides these inflammatory cells to the gut and binds to the mucosal address in cell adhesion molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on gut endothelial cells. The extent of the α4β7 receptor saturation by vedolizumab was assessed using the MAdCAM-1-Fc binding interference assay at time points where at least 50% of participants in the analysis set had non-missing results. MAdCAM-1-Fc is a fusion of human MAdCAM-1 with parts of a mouse monoclonal antibody. The assay measures the percentage of cells bearing α4β7 that were not saturated with vedolizumab at the time of sampling.

arm_group.description: Participants received vedolizumab, 2 mg/kg, intravenously (IV), on Days 1, 15 and 43, and thereafter once every 8 weeks for up to 78 weeks.
Participants received vedolizumab, 6 mg/kg, IV, on Days 1, 15 and 43, and thereafter once every 8 weeks for up to 78 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Confirmed and active ulcerative colitis (UC) or Crohn's Disease (CD)
- Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) Score of 220 - 450 for participants with CD
- Partial Mayo score of 2 - 7 for participants with UC
- Patient should be appropriate candidate for biologic therapy per guidelines
- Up-to-date on cancer screening
- No severe systemic disease
- Patients with evidence of abscess
- Agree to comply with study procedures including contraception
Exclusion Criteria:
- Low lymphocyte counts
- History of imaging abnormalities, multiple sclerosis (MS), brain tumor or other neurological illness
- Active or recent serious infections
- Recent treatment with biologic (i.e., Remicade) or investigational drug
- Impending surgery
- Any participants with vedolizumab human anti-human antibody (HAHA) titers ≥1:125 or with a previous immediate hypersensitivity reaction during or shortly after vedolizumab infusion

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants took part in the study at 14 investigative sites in Canada and Russia, between 07 December 2007 and 31 March 2010.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Treatment-naïve ulcerative colitis (UC) or Crohn's Disease (CD) participants were assigned to receive 6.0 mg/kg vedolizumab. Participants who rolled over from Study C13002 (NCT01177228) were assigned to receive 2.0 mg/kg vedolizumab.

group.title: Vedolizumab 2 mg/kg
group.description: Participants received vedolizumab, 2 mg/kg, intravenously (IV), on Days 1, 15 and 43, and thereafter once every 8 weeks for up to 78 weeks

group.description: Participants received vedolizumab, 6 mg/kg, IV, on Days 1, 15 and 43, and thereafter once every 8 weeks for up to 78 weeks

baseline.population: The Safety Analysis Set defined as all enrolled participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug. Patients were analyzed based on the lowest dose they received. Baseline is the time closest to, but before, the start of study drug administration; for participants who rolled over from Study C13002 Baseline data are from the C13002 dataset.

outcome.description: An adverse event (AE) is any untoward medical occurrence in a patient administered a pharmaceutical product, which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the treatment. The investigator systematically collected information adequate to determine both the outcome and severity of the AE, and whether or not it was drug-related or met the criteria for classification as a serious adverse event (SAE). An SAE was defined as an AE that resulted in (or posed risk for) death, inpatient hospitalization (or prolonging hospitalization), or congenital, persistent or significant disability/incapacity. The intensity for each AE was defined according to the following criteria: Mild: Awareness of sign or symptom, but easily tolerated; Moderate: Discomfort enough to cause interference with normal daily activities; Severe: Inability to perform normal daily activities.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Human Anti-human Antibodies (HAHA)

outcome.title: Serum Concentration of Vedolizumab Before Dosing
outcome.description: Vedolizumab serum concentrations were measured from serum samples collected for pharmacokinetic (PK) analysis within 2 hours prior to dosing. The original protocol specified that PK parameters, including but not limited to minimum plasma concentration (Cmin), were to be estimated; however, due to intrapatient dose modification with Amendment 1, it was no longer feasible to perform a full PK parameter estimation. The summaries of pre-infusion data (i.e., trough levels) are presented at time points where at least 50% of participants had quantifiable vedolizumab concentrations, using a value of 0 for results below a measurable range. This provides information on the pharmacokinetic behavior of vedolizumab when administered as long-term therapy.
outcome.population: The PK Population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of vedolizumab and had sufficient blood sampling for estimation of PK parameters. Participants without dose modification and with available serum concentration data at each time point (indicated by "n") are included.

measure.title: Serum Concentration of Vedolizumab Before Dosing
measure.description: Vedolizumab serum concentrations were measured from serum samples collected for pharmacokinetic (PK) analysis within 2 hours prior to dosing. The original protocol specified that PK parameters, including but not limited to minimum plasma concentration (Cmin), were to be estimated; however, due to intrapatient dose modification with Amendment 1, it was no longer feasible to perform a full PK parameter estimation. The summaries of pre-infusion data (i.e., trough levels) are presented at time points where at least 50% of participants had quantifiable vedolizumab concentrations, using a value of 0 for results below a measurable range. This provides information on the pharmacokinetic behavior of vedolizumab when administered as long-term therapy.
measure.population: The PK Population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of vedolizumab and had sufficient blood sampling for estimation of PK parameters. Participants without dose modification and with available serum concentration data at each time point (indicated by "n") are included.

outcome.title: Saturation of Receptors by Vedolizumab Before Dosing on Days 1, 43, 99, 155 and 267 by ACT-1 Assay
outcome.description: The target of vedolizumab is α4β7 integrin, a receptor found on inflammatory immune cells that guides these inflammatory cells to the gut and binds to the Mucosal Addressin Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on gut endothelial cells. The extent of the α4β7 receptor saturation by vedolizumab was assessed using the ACT-1 binding interference assay. ACT-1 is a mouse antibody similar to vedolizumab that also binds α4β7 integrin. The assay measures the percentage of cells bearing α4β7 that were not saturated with vedolizumab at the time of sampling.
outcome.population: Pharmacodynamic (PD) Population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of vedolizumab and had sufficient blood sampling for estimation of PD parameters. Participants without dose modification and with available PD data at each time point are included.

measure.title: Saturation of Receptors by Vedolizumab Before Dosing on Days 1, 43, 99, 155 and 267 by ACT-1 Assay
measure.description: The target of vedolizumab is α4β7 integrin, a receptor found on inflammatory immune cells that guides these inflammatory cells to the gut and binds to the Mucosal Addressin Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on gut endothelial cells. The extent of the α4β7 receptor saturation by vedolizumab was assessed using the ACT-1 binding interference assay. ACT-1 is a mouse antibody similar to vedolizumab that also binds α4β7 integrin. The assay measures the percentage of cells bearing α4β7 that were not saturated with vedolizumab at the time of sampling.
measure.population: Pharmacodynamic (PD) Population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of vedolizumab and had sufficient blood sampling for estimation of PD parameters. Participants without dose modification and with available PD data at each time point are included.

measurement_list.measurement: Data are not available because only treatment naïve participants were included at the Day 1 time point, and no naïve participants received 2 mg/kg.

outcome.title: Saturation of Receptors by Vedolizumab Before Dosing Using the MAdCAM-1-Fc Assay
outcome.description: The target of vedolizumab is α4β7 integrin, a receptor found on inflammatory immune cells that guides these inflammatory cells to the gut and binds to the mucosal address in cell adhesion molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on gut endothelial cells. The extent of the α4β7 receptor saturation by vedolizumab was assessed using the MAdCAM-1-Fc binding interference assay at time points where at least 50% of participants in the analysis set had non-missing results. MAdCAM-1-Fc is a fusion of human MAdCAM-1 with parts of a mouse monoclonal antibody. The assay measures the percentage of cells bearing α4β7 that were not saturated with vedolizumab at the time of sampling.
outcome.population: Pharmacodynamic (PD) Population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of vedolizumab and had sufficient blood sampling for estimation of PD parameters. Participants without dose modification and with available PD data at each time point are included.

event.description: Crohn’s Disease (CD) relapse among CD patients
Crohn’s Disease (CD) relapse among CD patients

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The first study related publication will be a multi-center publication submitted within 24 months after conclusion or termination of a study at all sites. After such multi-site publication, all proposed site publications and presentations will be submitted to sponsor for review 60 days in advance of publication. Site will remove Sponsor confidential information unrelated to study results. Sponsor can delay a proposed publication for another 60 days to preserve intellectual property.
